--- In archive-crawler@yahoogrou=
ps.com, "Gordon Mohr (archive.org)" 
<gojomo@a...> wrote:
>
> alxartes wrot=
e:
> > I am quite new with Heritrix and just started crawling websites.I 
w=
ould 
> > be very grateful if someone can provide some answers to the 
foll=
owing 
> > inquiries.
> > 
> > 1. Does Heritrix produce a DAT file aside fr=
om the ARC file? Is 
there 
> > an open source tool that can extract the da=
t file from the arc 
file? We 
> > need the meta data like-contents of the =
DAT file.
> 
> We don't have DAT-writing capabilities as part of the Heritr=
ix 
package.
> There's a '--store' option mentioned in the Bnf ARC Tools
> =
(http://crawler.archive.org/cgi-bin/wiki.pl?BnfArcTools) that I 
believe
> =
can create DATs; I've inquired with the author for more details.
> 
> > 2. =
How does Heritrix verify that the files that it downloaded are 
not 
> > co=
rrupted? Does it use md5 checksum?
> 
> The only guard against corruption d=
uring HTTP download is that 
provided
> by the protocols: TCP/IP checksums =
(and, when using HTTPS, its 
integrity
> checks).
> 
> A SHA1 checksum of t=
he HTTP response originally received is taken 
on the
> fly and stored in t=
he crawl.log for later reference.
> 
> Other collection-management systems =
(completely separate from the 
crawler)
> monitor the archived disk files (=
mainly ARCs) for decay or other 
corruption.
> 
> - Gordon @ IA
>
